It is difficult to answer a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences others may prove impossible for you to answer so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Write in detail or give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Plots That Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered it, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark those ones you would be willing to answer.

All questionnaires

- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experiences

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of its permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaires to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

HEMSTREET OF REGINA AT INDIANHEAD 60TH

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

My life of early days were in the home of a pioneer physician Dr. E.W. Hunt. His home was away from everything with no hospital. I often thought of my mother getting father ready to go out my three storms to McLean, Ellsworth, Wolsley, and Merbury. Away from the town of Indian Head. Even as a very small child my job was to get the milk from our cow daily put it on the bus and then back to the field after school around noon and bring dinner to church.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far?

Yes I travel quite a lot. Draw a lot with my father on the trips also by train and as to message from Regina and Winnipeg. But aside we used to wait back east.

HEMSTREET OF REGINA AT INDIANHEAD OCT 11TH

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stand out in your memory which you would like to record?

My life of early days were in the home of a pioneer physician Dr. C.W. Hunt. The Dr's home was everything with no hospital. I often think of my mother getting father ready to go out into those storms to McLean, Ellisboro, Wolseley, Summerbury, away North of Indian Head. Even as a very small child my job was to get the big shawl on one half & put paper then put other half over that. Mother then put this over father's head and tied a scarf around this and in this way it would protect his face.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Yes I travel quite a lot. I drove a lot with my father on his trips. Also by train such as to Moose Jaw, Regina, and Winnipeg. Besides we used to visit back east.

I moved when I was married to Regina but father & mother never left India Head.
